user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl(uint32 ModeBits)
{
    char param[32];

    if (OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.EnableTermControl)
    {
        if (ModeBits == OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL)
        {
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("sgr0", NULL);
        }
        else
        {
            if ((ModeBits & OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT) == 0)
            {
                /* no highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("rmso", NULL);
            }
            else
            {
                /* set highlight (standout) text */
                OS_BSP_ExecTput("smso", NULL);
            }

            snprintf(param, sizeof(param), "%d", OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(ModeBits));
            OS_BSP_ExecTput("setaf", param);
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_ConsoleSetMode_Impl:
static void OS_BSP_ExecTput(const char *cap, const char *param)
{
    pid_t cpid;
    int   status;

    cpid = fork();
    if (cpid < 0)
    {
        return;
    }
    if (cpid == 0)
    {
        execlp("tput", "tput", cap, param, NULL);
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }
    waitpid(cpid, &status, 0);
}
...
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR(x) ((x)&0x07)
...
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_NORMAL 0x0
...
#define OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_HIGHLIGHT 0x8
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code. The fragments present are standard C language constructs and standard/POSIX library interfaces, not compiler-specific extensions: - Control structures (if/else, return), function definitions, static storage class, char arrays, snprintf and macros are standard C (snprintf is C99). - Bitwise operations and macro-based constants (OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_*, OS_BSP_CONSOLEMODE_TO_ANSICOLOR) are preprocessor features and standard C expressions. - pid_t, fork(), execlp(), waitpid(), exit(), and related headers are POSIX APIs, not compiler language extensions (they are platform/library calls). - No use of known compiler-specific extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({:}), nested functions, or other vendor-specific keywords or builtins is present. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions should not be used).
